El pintor, un hombre de edad madura con un bigote bien cuidado y un sombrero de fieltro, se acercó un poco más a su modelo, examinando cada detalle de su rostro, buscando la perfección en cada línea y cada curva. El aire en la habitación era tenso, lleno de expectativas, como si el resultado de la sesión de pintura fuera a ser algo más que solo un simple retrato.

But I can understand the beauty of a sunset, the joy of a child's laughter, the peace of a quiet forest. I can see the beauty in the world, but I cannot feel the pain. It is a strange dichotomy, one that I have always struggled with. I have tried to understand the suffering of others, to put myself in their shoes and feel their pain, but it is a feeling that eludes me. I can only observe it, never truly experience it. And yet, I am drawn to it, fascinated by the way it can transform people, make them stronger, more resilient. I see it in the eyes of those who have endured hardship, a glint of steel, a spark of determination. It is a quality that I admire, one that I wish I could possess myself. But for now, I am stuck in my own world, unable to truly connect with the suffering of others. I can only watch from the sidelines, a detached observer, a philosopher who can see the beauty in the world, but not the pain.

He leaned against the doorframe, his tall figure casting a long shadow across the floor, as he watched her with an air of quiet satisfaction. The soft glow of the candles in the room seemed to dance across her face, highlighting the subtle curves of her features and the sparkle in her eyes. She, on the other hand, seemed oblivious to the effect she was having on him, her gaze fixed on some point beyond his shoulder, her expression a mask of calm and composure. But Lord Henry knew better, he had seen the flash of awareness in her eyes, the fleeting moment of connection that had passed between them like a spark of electricity. He smiled to himself, a low, husky sound that seemed to vibrate through the air, as he pushed away from the doorframe and began to move towards her, his long strides eating up the distance between them.

Al mirarse en el espejo, vio reflejada la imagen de un hombre apuesto y sofisticado, con un bigote bien peinado y un abrigo de seda que le sentaba a la perfección. Pero detrás de esa fachada de elegancia, se escondía un hombre con un pasado oscuro y un corazón lleno de dudas y miedos. La luz del espejo iluminó su rostro, y por un momento, se vio a sí mismo tal como era en realidad: un hombre solo y perdido en un mundo que parecía haber cambiado sin que él se diera cuenta. La imagen se desvaneció, y lord Henry se dio cuenta de que no podía seguir viviendo en el pasado, que debía enfrentar el presente y encontrar una forma de superar sus miedos y dudas para poder seguir adelante.

en_first_half: “It is an interesting question,” said Lord Henry, who found an exquisite pleasure in playing on the lad’s unconscious egotism, “an extremely interesting question. I fancy that the true explanation is this: It often happens that the real tragedies of life occur in such an inartistic manner that they hurt us by their crude violence, their absolute incoherence, their absurd want of meaning, their entire lack of style. They affect us just as vulgarity affects us. They give us an impression of sheer brute force, and we revolt against that. Sometimes, however, a tragedy that possesses artistic elements of beauty crosses our lives. If these elements of beauty are real, the whole thing simply appeals to our sense of dramatic effect. Suddenly we find that we are no longer the actors, but the spectators of the play. Or rather we are both. We watch ourselves,
en_second_half: and the mere wonder of the spectacle enthralls us. In the present case, what is it that has really happened? Some one has killed herself for love of you. I wish that I had ever had such an experience. It would have made me in love with love for the rest of my life. The people who have adored me—there have not been very many, but there have been some—have always insisted on living on, long after I had ceased to care for them, or they to care for me. They have become stout and tedious, and when I meet them, they go in at once for reminiscences. That awful memory of woman! What a fearful thing it is! And what an utter intellectual stagnation it reveals! One should absorb the colour of life, but one should never remember its details. Details are always vulgar.”

The tragedy becomes a mirror, reflecting back to us our own hopes and fears, our desires and our doubts. And it is in this reflection that we find a strange and beautiful sense of catharsis, a release from the burden of our own egos and the weight of our own expectations. The tragedy becomes a kind of liberation, a freedom to see the world in all its beauty and ugliness, to accept it for what it is, and to find a sense of peace in the midst of chaos. But, of course, this is not always the case. Sometimes, the tragedy is not a beautiful thing at all. Sometimes it is a brutal and senseless event, a cruel twist of fate that leaves us reeling and lost. In these moments, we are forced to confront the abyss of uncertainty that lies at the heart of human existence. We are faced with the possibility that our lives may be nothing more than a series of random events, a meaningless sequence of cause and effect with no underlying purpose or design. It is in these moments that we are forced to confront our own mortality, to face the fact that we are all just temporary visitors in this vast and mysterious universe. And it is in this confrontation that we find a strange and profound sense of humility, a recognition that our own lives are but a small part of a much larger story, a story that is still being written, and one that we can only dimly see. es_first_half: —Es un caso interesante —dijo lord Henry, que encontraba un placer sutil enjugar con el egoísmo inconsciente de su joven amigo—; un caso sumamente interesante. Creo que la verdadera explicación es ésta: sucede con frecuencia que las tragedias reales de la vida ocurren de una manera tan poco artística que nos hieren por lo crudo de su violencia, por su absoluta incoherencia, su absurda ausencia de significado, su completa falta de estilo. Nos afectan como lo hace la vulgaridad. Sólo nos producen una impresión de fuerza bruta, y nos rebelamos contra eso. A veces, sin embargo, cruza nuestras vidas una tragedia que posee elementos de belleza artística. Si esos elementos de belleza son reales, todo el conjunto apela a nuestro sentido del efecto dramático. De repente descubrimos que ya no somos los actores, sino los espectadores de la obra. O que
es_second_half: somos más bien las dos cosas. Nos observamos, y el mero asombro del espectáculo nos seduce. En el caso presente, ¿qué es lo que ha sucedido en realidad? Alguien se ha matado por amor tuyo. Me gustaría haber tenido alguna vez una experiencia semejante. Me hubiera hecho enamorarme del amor para el resto de mi vida. Las personas que me han adorado (no han sido muchas, pero sí algunas), siempre han insistido en seguir viviendo después de que yo dejase de quererlas y ellas dejaran de quererme a mí. Se han vuelto corpulentas y tediosas, y cuando me encuentro con ellas se lanzan inmediatamente a los recuerdos. ¡Ah, esa terrible memoria de las mujeres! ¡Qué cosa más espantosa! ¡Y qué total estancamiento intelectual revela! Se deben absorberlos colores de la vida, pero nunca recordar los detalles. Los detalles siempre son vulgares.
es_results: la vida es una obra de arte, y que nosotros somos los espectadores que se ven obligados a asistir a una representación que no podemos evitar. Y es en ese momento cuando nos damos cuenta de que la tragedia no es solo una serie de eventos desafortunados, sino una obra maestra que nos hace reflexionar sobre la condición humana. La belleza de la tragedia radica en su capacidad para evocar emociones profundas y para hacernos sentir la conexión con la humanidad que nos rodea. Es en ese instante cuando la vida se vuelve más rica y más significativa, y cuando nos damos cuenta de que la verdadera tragedia no es la pérdida o la desgracia, sino la falta de comprensión y la falta de conexión con lo que nos rodea. The paparazzi were swarming outside his office building, and his phone was blowing up with calls from reporters and friends trying to get a statement from him. The thought sent a shiver down his spine as he gazed at the portrait, the painting that had become a constant reminder of his descent into madness. He had hidden it away for so long, afraid of what others might think, but now he was beginning to wonder if it was time to reveal the truth. The painting seemed to be calling to him, its eyes seeming to gleam with a malevolent intensity in the dim light of the room. Dorian's heart was racing as he considered the possibility of exposing his dark secret to the world, and the potential consequences that might follow. He knew it would be a risk, but a part of him was eager to be free of the burden of secrecy, to unshackle himself from the weight of his own guilt and shame. The question was, would he be able to live with the repercussions of his actions, or would the world's reaction be too much for him to bear?

es_results_raw: ahora se encontraba en un rincón de la biblioteca, olvidado y cubierto de polvo, como si hubiera sido abandonado por completo. Dorian se acercó a él con cuidado, no quería tocarlo con las manos sucias, y lo levantó con delicadeza. El satén era suave al tacto, pero el olor a polvo y moho era intenso. Se lo llevó a la nariz y lo olió con curiosidad, recordando las historias que su abuelo le había contado sobre el convento y sus habitantes. Según él, el convento había sido un lugar de gran espiritualidad y arte, donde las monjas habían tejido aquel cubrecama con amor y dedicación. Dorian se sintió conmovido al pensar en la historia detrás de aquel objeto, y decidió que sí, serviría perfectamente para envolver el lienzo. Pero antes de hacerlo, se detuvo a pensar en la forma en que su abuelo había encontrado el cubrecama. ¿Qué había estado haciendo en un convento tan lejano? ¿Qué lo había llevado a buscar en aquel lugar? Dorian se preguntó, pero no encontró respuestas en el cubrecama, solo la imagen de su abuelo sonriendo, con una mirada de satisfacción en su rostro. Se sintió conmovido y decidió seguir adelante con su plan, sabiendo que su abuelo estaría de acuerdo con su decisión. Con cuidado, envolvió el cubrecama alrededor del lienzo, y se sintió satisfecho con la forma en que quedaba. Ahora, solo le quedaba encontrar un lugar adecuado para enterrarlo, un lugar donde nadie lo encontraría jamás. Dorian se puso a pensar en los lugares que conocía, pero ninguno parecía adecuado. Fue entonces cuando recordó la casa de campo de su familia, ubicada en un bosque lejano. Allí, el lienzo estaría a salvo, rodeado de árboles y silencio. Se sintió aliviado al pensar en la seguridad que le brindaría ese lugar, y decidió que allí sería donde enterraría el lienzo. Con la decisión tomada, se dirigió hacia la salida, listo para enfrentar el camino que lo llevaría a su destino final.

en_first_half: Of such insolences and attempted slights he, of course, took no notice, and in the opinion of most people his frank debonair manner, his charming boyish smile, and the infinite grace of that wonderful youth that seemed never to leave him, were in themselves a sufficient answer to the calumnies, for so they termed them, that were circulated
en_second_half: about him. It was remarked, however, that some of those who had been most intimate with him appeared, after a time, to shun him. Women who had wildly adored him, and for his sake had braved all social censure and set convention at defiance, were seen to grow pallid with shame or horror if Dorian Gray entered the room.
en_results: of the malicious gossip that had been spread about him. His reputation, however, was not the only thing that was being tested during this time. His relationships with those close to him were also being put to the ultimate test, as the weight of his family's expectations and the pressures of his own ambitions began to bear
en_results_raw: of the malicious gossip that had been spread about him. His reputation, however, was not the only thing that was being tested during this time. His relationships with those close to him were also being put to the ultimate test, as the weight of his family's expectations and the pressures of his own ambitions began to bear down upon him. His parents, though well-intentioned, were often at odds with one another, their differing opinions on how he should be raised and the kind of person he should become causing tension in the household. His friends, on the other hand, were a lively and boisterous bunch, always up for a good time and never afraid to speak their minds. They looked up to him as a leader, and he, in turn, felt a sense of responsibility to them, to be a role model and a source of guidance. But as he navigated the complexities of his relationships with those around him, he couldn't shake the feeling that he was being pulled in too many different directions, that he was being forced to choose between the life he wanted and the life that was expected of him. The pressure was mounting, and he knew that he had to find a way to reconcile his own desires with the demands of those around him, or risk losing himself in the process.

He felt a sense of unease wash over him, as if he was being watched, and his heart began to pound in his chest. The chill that had started as a mere tremble now spread throughout his body, making him shiver uncontrollably. La llama crepitaba y chispeaba, iluminando su rostro con un brillo extraño. De repente, se le ocurrió una idea y se dirigió hacia la biblioteca, donde sabía que había un libro sobre la historia de la casa. Al abrir el libro, encontró una página marcada con una nota que decía: "No te acerques a la chimenea". La nota estaba escrita con una letra que parecía familiar, pero que no podía recordar dónde la había visto antes.

en_first_half: Dorian half opened the door. As he did so, he saw the face of his portrait leering in the sunlight. On the floor in front of it the torn curtain was lying. He

en_results_raw: stepped back, his eyes fixed on the painting, and for a moment, he felt a shiver run down his spine. The face in the portrait seemed to be watching him, its eyes following his every move. He tried to shake off the feeling, telling himself it was just his imagination, but he couldn't help but feel a sense of unease. The torn curtain, which had been ripped from its hooks, lay crumpled on the floor, its threads tangled and frayed. He wondered who could have done such a thing, and why. As he stood there, frozen in thought, he became aware of a faint scent in the air, a sweet and heady aroma that seemed to be coming from the direction of the painting. It was a smell he knew all too well, a smell that brought back memories of his past, of the life he had left behind. He felt a pang of nostalgia wash over him, and for a moment, he was transported back to a time when life was simpler, when his only worry was the pursuit of beauty and pleasure. But as the scent faded, he was brought back to the present, and the reality of his situation hit him like a ton of bricks. He was trapped, trapped in a life he didn't want, trapped in a world that was slowly suffocating him. The face in the portrait seemed to be watching him, its eyes gleaming with a knowing glint, as if it too knew the truth about his situation. Dorian felt a surge of anger and frustration, and for a moment, he wanted to lash out, to destroy the painting and the life it represented. But he knew he couldn't, not yet. He was still trapped, still bound by the chains of his own making. And so he stood there, frozen in indecision, as the face in the portrait seemed to mock him, its eyes glinting with a cruel amusement.

en_first_half: “Of course it is true, Lord Henry. If we women did not love you for your defects, where would you all be? Not one of you would ever be married.
en_second_half: You would be a set of unfortunate bachelors. Not, however, that that would alter you much. Nowadays all the married men live like bachelors, and all the bachelors like married men.”
en_results: But, my dear, you are being facetious, as always. The truth is, we love you for your charming flaws, your witty remarks, and your ability to make us laugh when we need it most. Your
en_results_raw: But, my dear, you are being facetious, as always. The truth is, we love you for your charming flaws, your witty remarks, and your ability to make us laugh when we need it most. Your imperfections are what make you human, and it's those very qualities that draw us to you. If you were perfect, we would find you dull and uninteresting. But as it is, you are a breath of fresh air, a ray of sunshine on a cloudy day. Your defects are what make you lovable, and we adore you for them. But tell me, Lord Henry, have you ever stopped to think about the consequences of your words? Do you truly believe that we women are so desperate for love that we would settle for a man with no redeeming qualities just because he is handsome and charming? I think not. We may be foolish, but we are not that foolish. We want more than just a pretty face and a quick wit. We want a man with a heart, a man who can love us for who we are, and who will stand by us through thick and thin. And I must say, I am not convinced that you possess those qualities, Lord Henry. But I do believe that you are a fascinating study, a puzzle to be solved, and I am intrigued by your complexities. So, I will continue to watch you, to observe you, and to learn from you. But I will not be swayed by your charm and good looks alone. I want to see substance, Lord Henry. I want to see depth. And until I see that, I will remain skeptical of your intentions.

en_first_half: It is said that passion makes one think in a circle. Certainly with hideous iteration the bitten lips of Dorian Gray shaped and reshaped those subtle words that dealt with soul and sense, till he had found in them the full expression, as it were, of his mood, and justified, by intellectual approval, passions that without such justification would still have dominated his temper. From cell to cell of his brain crept the one thought; and the wild desire to live, most terrible of all man’s appetites, quickened
en_second_half: into force each trembling nerve and fibre. Ugliness that had once been hateful to him because it made things real, became dear to him now for that very reason. Ugliness was the one reality. The coarse brawl, the loathsome den, the crude violence of disordered life, the very vileness of thief and outcast, were more vivid, in their intense actuality of impression, than all the gracious shapes of art, the dreamy shadows of song. They were what he needed for forgetfulness. In three days he would be free.
en_results: into a fever that could not be assuaged, a burning flame that consumed him, body and soul. His eyes, once bright and full of life, now seemed to hold a dark and sinister light, a light that seemed to burn with an inner fire that could not be extinguished. The words he spoke, the thoughts he thought, were all consumed by this one all-encompassing passion, a passion that drove him to seek out new experiences, new sensations, new pleasures, no matter the cost. And yet, despite the turmoil that raged within
en_results_raw: The wild desire to live, most terrible of all man's appetites, quickened into a fever that could not be assuaged, a burning flame that consumed him, body and soul. His eyes, once bright and full of life, now seemed to hold a dark and sinister light, a light that seemed to burn with an inner fire that could not be extinguished. The words he spoke, the thoughts he thought, were all consumed by this one all-encompassing passion, a passion that drove him to seek out new experiences, new sensations, new pleasures, no matter the cost. And yet, despite the turmoil that raged within him, he was calm, serene, and collected, his mask of civility and refinement intact, hiding the turmoil that churned beneath the surface. His was a life of contradictions, a life of beauty and ugliness, of light and darkness, of passion and control. And as he walked through the streets, a figure of elegance and refinement, he was a man consumed by his own desires, a man torn between the beauty of art and the ugliness of his own soul.

La habitación estaba llena de sombras, y el aire estaba cargado de un silencio que parecía pesar sobre él. Dorian se sintió atraído por la oscuridad, como si algo lo estuviera llamando desde allí. Con una mezcla de curiosidad y temor, se adentró en la habitación, sus ojos intentando adaptarse a la penumbra. El olor a opio parecía haberse intensificado, y su respiración se volvió más superficial. Allí, en la oscuridad, encontró una figura sentada en una silla, envuelta en una capa oscura que parecía flotar en el aire. La figura no parecía estar respirando, y su rostro estaba completamente inerte. Dorian se sintió congelado en el lugar, incapaz de moverse o hablar. La figura parecía estar esperándolo, como si hubiera estado allí esperando su llegada. De repente, la figura comenzó a hablar, su voz tan baja que apenas se podía escuchar, pero que parecía resonar en el interior de Dorian. "¿Qué buscas, Dorian?", preguntó la figura, su voz como un susurro que parecía provenir de la nada. Dorian se sintió conmocionado, pero logró encontrar las palabras para responder. "¿Quién eres?", preguntó, su voz temblorosa. La figura no respondió, pero en su lugar, comenzó a sonreír, y su rostro pareció iluminarse con una luz que no parecía provenir de ninguna parte. Dorian se sintió aterrorizado, pero también fascinado por la figura y su misteriosa presencia. en_results_raw: <output>The forest was alive with the sounds of the hunt, and Dorian felt a thrill run through him as he walked alongside his friend, the trees towering above them like sentinels of a secret world. The scent of damp earth and decaying leaves filled his nostrils, and the rustle of leaves beneath their feet was the only sound that broke the spell of the moment. They walked in silence for a while, the only sound being the distant beat of the drum and the occasional shout of the beaters as they drove the game deeper into the forest. The trees grew denser here, their branches tangled together in a canopy above, filtering the sunlight and casting the forest floor in a soft, emerald green glow. Dorian felt a sense of peace wash over him as he breathed in the crisp air, the stress and worries of the world left behind in the city. His friend, a seasoned hunter, seemed to sense his mood and nodded in understanding, his eyes scanning the forest floor for any sign of their quarry. The beaters were getting closer, their shouts growing louder as they closed in on their target, and Dorian felt his heart pounding in anticipation. He had been on many hunts before, but there was something about this one that felt different, something that made him feel alive and connected to the natural world in a way he never had before. The trees seemed to be watching him, their branches swaying gently in the breeze as if they too were waiting for the outcome of the hunt. Dorian's friend stopped suddenly, his hand raised in a signal for silence, and Dorian followed his gaze to a small clearing up ahead. In the center of the clearing stood a magnificent stag, its antlers towering above the underbrush, its eyes fixed intently on the beaters as they closed in. Dorian felt a surge of excitement run through him as he reached for his rifle, his heart pounding in his chest. This was it, the moment he had been waiting for. The beaters were getting closer, their shouts growing louder, and Dorian knew that he had to be quick if he wanted to get a shot. He took a deep breath, his finger tightening on the trigger as he waited for the perfect moment to fire. The beaters were almost upon them now, their shouts echoing through the forest as they closed in on their quarry. Dorian's heart was racing, his senses on high alert as he waited for the perfect shot. And then, in a flash of movement, it was over. The beaters had driven the stag into a frenzy, and Dorian had fired his rifle, the sound echoing through the forest as the stag crashed to the ground. Dorian felt a rush of adrenaline as he approached the fallen animal, his friend by his side. They stood there for a moment, taking in the scene, the beaters closing in to help them bring down the stag. It was over, and Dorian felt a sense of pride and accomplishment wash over him. He had done it, and he knew that this was just the beginning of a new chapter in his life. The forest was quiet once more, the only sound being the distant beat of the drum as the beaters made their way back to the village. Dorian and his friend stood there for a moment, taking in the silence, before turning to make their way back to the village, the stag slung over their shoulders. They walked in silence, the only sound being the rustle of leaves beneath their feet, as they made their way back to the village, the thrill of the hunt still coursing through their veins. As they emerged from the forest, Dorian caught a glimpse of the village in the distance, the thatched roofs of the huts glinting in the sunlight. He felt a sense of pride and accomplishment wash over him as he looked out at the village, knowing that he had provided for his people. The villagers would be proud of him, and he knew that he had done something truly special. He felt a sense of connection to the land and the people, a sense of belonging that he had never felt before. The hunt had been a success, and Dorian knew that this was just the beginning of a new chapter in his life. He looked over at his friend, who was smiling at him, and nodded in understanding. They had done it, and they knew that they would always be remembered as the ones who had brought back the stag. The villagers would be proud of them, and Dorian knew that he had truly earned his place among them. As they walked into the village, the villagers looked up at them with a mixture of curiosity and admiration, their faces lighting up with smiles as they took in the sight of the stag slung over their shoulders. es_results_raw: ha sido de ti durante todo este tiempo, pero no se atreve a acercarse. El jardín, que en otros tiempos fue un lugar de deleite y tranquilidad, ahora parece un laberinto de sombras y misterios. El jardinero, un hombre de edad avanzada con un rostro cansado y una mirada triste, se encuentra paralizado en el umbral de la entrada, como si no supiera cómo abordar la situación. Lord Henry, con una sonrisa enigmática, se acerca a él con pasos lentos y silenciosos, como si no quisiera perturbar el silencio que reina en el jardín. El jardinero, al verlo acercarse, se estremece ligeramente, como si temiera lo que podría suceder a continuación. Lord Henry se detiene frente a él y, con una voz suave y persuasiva, le pregunta: "¿Qué es lo que te trae aquí hoy, amigo mío?" El jardinero, con una voz temblorosa, responde: "Sólo quería... sólo quería preguntarte... ¿sabes algo sobre... sobre lo que ha pasado?" Lord Henry asiente con la cabeza, como si supiera exactamente de qué hablaba el jardinero, y responde: "Sí, amigo mío, sé algo. Sé que ha sido un tiempo difícil para todos, pero no sé qué es lo que te preocupa en particular." El jardinero se estremece de nuevo, como si temiera que Lord Henry supiera más de lo que decía, y responde: "No sé... no sé qué es lo que te hace pensar eso." Lord Henry sonríe de nuevo, como si disfrutara de la situación, y responde: "Sólo que sé que hay algo que te preocupa, algo que te hace temblar de miedo. ¿Quieres hablar sobre ello?" El jardinero, con una mirada desesperada, asiente con la cabeza, como si supiera que no tenía otra opción. Lord Henry, con una sonrisa enigmática, se acerca a él y le dice: "Habla, amigo mío, habla. Sé que puedo ayudarte." El jardinero, con una voz temblorosa, comienza a hablar, y Lord Henry, con una mirada atenta, escucha atentamente cada palabra que sale de su boca.

en_results_raw: “I have been good, I have been very good, but it is no use telling you that you are going to be good when you are not even good now. You are a reckless, selfish, and arrogant young man, and I fear that you will never change your ways. Your mother would be appalled if she knew the company you keep and the things you do. She would be heartbroken if she knew the influence you are under, and the people you are associating with. You must be careful, my boy, for you are playing with fire and you may get burned. I am warning you, for your own good, to be more mindful of your actions and to surround yourself with people who will guide you towards the right path, not lead you further astray. I know you think you know it all, but trust me, you do not. You are young and foolish, and you need guidance. I am offering it to you now, but I fear it may be too late. You must listen to me, for your own sake, and for the sake of your family's reputation, which you are rapidly tarnishing with your reckless behavior. I implore you, for the love of all that is good and decent, to change your ways and become a better person. You have the potential, but you must be willing to listen and learn. I am here to help you, but you must be willing to accept my guidance. I fear that if you do not, you will be lost forever, and that thought is a terrible one to contemplate.”

en_first_half: “My dear boy,” said Lord Henry, smiling, “anybody can be good in the country. There are no temptations there. That is the reason why people who live out of town are so absolutely uncivilized. Civilization is not by any
en_second_half: means an easy thing to attain to. There are only two ways by which man can reach it. One is by being cultured, the other by being corrupt. Country people have no opportunity of being either, so they stagnate.”
en_results: impossible without the presence of temptation. It is the struggle against temptation that makes us human. And it is in the city, where the temptations are numerous and varied, that we find the true test of our
en_results_raw: impossible without the presence of temptation. It is the struggle against temptation that makes us human. And it is in the city, where the temptations are numerous and varied, that we find the true test of our character. The country, on the other hand, is a place where people are often so isolated and sheltered from the world that they lack the opportunity to develop their moral fibre. But, my dear boy, do not think that I am advocating for a life of debauchery and excess. No, I am merely saying that it is in the city, with all its vices and virtues, that we find the true essence of human nature. It is there that we must learn to navigate the complexities of life, to make choices, and to forge our own path. And it is there, in the midst of all the chaos and uncertainty, that we discover our true character. So, let us not be afraid of the city, but rather let us embrace it, with all its challenges and opportunities, and let us strive to become the best version of ourselves.

en_first_half: “My dear fellow,” said Lord Henry, elevating his eyebrows in surprise, “I asked you because I thought you might be able to give me an answer. That is all. I was going through the park last Sunday, and close by the Marble Arch there stood a little crowd of shabby-looking people listening to some vulgar street-preacher. As I passed by, I heard the man yelling out that question to his audience. It struck me as being rather dramatic. London
en_second_half: is very rich in curious effects of that kind. A wet Sunday, an uncouth Christian in a mackintosh, a ring of sickly white faces under a broken roof of dripping umbrellas, and a wonderful phrase flung into the air by shrill hysterical lips—it was really very good in its way, quite a suggestion. I thought of telling the prophet that art had a soul, but that man had not. I am afraid, however, he would not have understood me.”

en_results_raw: London is a city that never sleeps, and yet, in that moment, it seemed to be at a standstill, frozen in time as the preacher's words hung in the air like a challenge. The crowd, a mix of the downtrodden and the desperate, hung on his every word, their faces a picture of hope and despair. The preacher, a man with a wild look in his eye and a voice that could charm the birds from the trees, was a master of his craft, weaving a tale of sin and redemption that seemed to speak directly to the souls of his listeners. As I watched, a young woman stepped forward, her eyes shining with a mixture of fear and determination, and asked the question that had been echoing in my mind since I first heard it: "What is the meaning of life?"
